awd_titl_txt: Design of Catalysts for Cooperative Substrate Activation
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Nathaniel Szymczak of the University of Michigan Ann Arbor is leading a research project on the synthesis of new kinds of catalysts.  The new catalysts bind starting materials by "multipoint interactions". This new approach provides a way to control chemical reactions and differs from traditional methods. The project examines how catalyst structures affect the speed and selectivity of the chemical reactions. One target reaction is the splitting of carbon-hydrogen bonds.  Another theme tests the insertion of carbon monoxide into metal-carbon bonds. Both processes underpin the production of fuels, commodity chemicals, and pharmaceuticals. Professor Szymczak is also developing a national outreach program to engage students in aspects of scientific research and data interpretation. To further raise scientific literacy among younger students, he and his graduate and undergraduate students are engaging with students at local events and schools.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Nathaniel Szymczak of the University of Michigan Ann Arbor is uncovering new strategies to make and break chemical bonds to carbon in organic molecules. These reactions are central in chemical synthesis, encompassing many industrial sectors, including petrochemical, materials development, and pharmaceutical production. In this project, Professor Szymczak is developing transition metal compounds that contain multiple reactive sites in order to promote difficult chemical reactions using widely available chemical feedstocks. This approach advances the basic science needed to develop molecular catalysts for sustainable chemical production by targeting strategies that promote highly specific chemical reactions from cheap chemical precursors, applicable to many fields. The broader impacts of this work include societal benefits from the discovery of low-energy chemical conversion strategies that might ultimately be adapted to earth-abundant metals. In addition, undergraduate and graduate students are undergoing interdisciplinary scientific training to prepare them for careers in teaching, in industrial chemistry, at a national lab, or in public policy. Professor Szymczak is developing a nationwide meeting series across multiple institutional levels to engage students in aspects of scientific research and data interpretation. To further raise scientific literacy among younger students, he and his graduate and undergraduate students are engaging with students at numerous local events and schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This NSF proposal focused on delineating acidity relationships between assorted strength Lewis acids and properties of metal-coordinated substrate/acid adducts. These included both inter- and intramolecular Lewis acid-substrate interactions, reactivity studies, determination of electronic structure, and thermodynamic properties. Strong Lewis acids are often used as co-additives to promote substrate activation/functionalization at single metal centers; however, they are often not compatible with the catalytic reactions because they can be quenched by either products (inhibiting product release), or basic sites on a ligand (inhibiting metalation). To overcome these problems, our work parameterized the effects of many Lewis acids on the electronic donor properties of distinct ligands for a fixed transition metal complex (Ni(CO)3-L) and uncovered principles needed for inter- vs. intramolecular Lewis acid binding. We anticipate that the results of these studies can serve as a guide for understanding how Lewis acidity can broadly influence substrate activation within transition-metal complexes and will be most impactful in ligand development with appended Lewis acids: weakly Lewis acidic groups are predicted to play similar roles to strong Lewis acids if structurally biased to do so.

In another area, we investigated electronic impacts of adding Lewis acids to a remote site on a ligand. Our work built on prior precedent to show that late-stage functionalization with Lewis acids modulates the ligand electronics and substrate (hydride) basicity. Using an appended –OH donor that can engage in dynamic H+/H- exchange with a Ir-H (~103 s-1), we evaluated effects of  incorporating varied remote Lewis acids and found that they either cause large (3 fold) rate differences at 25 °C, or alternatively, turn off the H+/H- exchange.

In another area, we developed synthetic strategies to incorporate Lewis acids within a metal’s secondary coordination sphere. Late-stage functionalization of already metalated ligands is a straightforward diversification strategy to enable modular modifications to an already active metal catalyst . Most current strategies use hydroboration of an appended olefin. We detailed numerous compatibility hurdles with hydroboration that include: (1) formation of intra/intermolecular Lewis acid/base pairs, (2) ancillary ligand abstraction by the borane, and (3) metal-centered reactivity. We prepared a series of borane-appended pincer ligands, we established methods to identify hurdles, and introduced diagnostic spectroscopic features that can be employed as a roadmap for ligand design. We anticipate that this approach will provide guidance to others in the community when designing routes to install Lewis acids within other ligand platforms.

In another study, we presented a late-stage functionalization route to assemble phosphinimine R3P=NR from the corresponding phosphine. Through a click-like Staudinger reaction, we showed that the addition of a series of aryl azides form five-coordinate Fe(II) phosphinimine compounds with distinct electronic properties. The methodology is robust and can be used as a general strategy for late-stage functionalization to incorporate Lewis acids.

In another area, we probed distance-dependent relationships to understand factors that impart cooperative substrate binding. We showed an interplay of Lewis acid strength within a distance threshold is required to facilitate cooperative substrate capture. This contribution highlights two key components that are challenging to study, and often overlooked: 1) cooperativity is substrate and distance dependent, and 2) a balance of enthalpic and entropic contributions to acid/base interactions is needed for reversible substrate binding. These two components are intertwined, and our methodical approach demonstrated how subtle changes to acid/base binding energies can favor/disfavor metal-ligand cooperativity.  Overall, these studies elucidated important design strategies to facilitate binding of metal-coordinated substrates with Lewis acids, as well as their associated thermodynamics, and we anticipate many of these concepts will be beneficial to the community.

Broader Impacts

The NSF grant involved the training of four graduate students, one visiting scholar, and a postdoc. Support for these members was supplemented by departmental teaching. These students were trained in inorganic and organometallic synthesis, catalysis, and mechanistic chemistry. Broader training involves aspects of professional development such emphasizing scientific communication through writing and presentations. Of the graduate students trained on prior NSF grants, three students secured postdoctoral positions (Berkeley, Princeton, Columbia; of those, one is an Assistant Professor (Weill Cornell University), two work at National Labs (Los Alamos and PNNL), and two secured jobs in the chemical industry (3M and Cabot).

Another area of recent NSF-supported Broader Impacts is the development of a platform for students to engage in scientific discussions across multiple institutional levels (R1, R2, PUIs) to facilitate an open dialogue of how research questions are approached and data interpreted. The meeting, called Interactive Collaborative Inorganic Discussion (iCID), was developed with a co-PI, John Gilbertson at Western Washington University, and we have finished the pilot phase of the program, which now includes research groups from UM, WWU, UC-Irvine, Cal Poly Pomona, and Drury University. Presentations are typically led by graduate students or postdocs and include interactive activities and breakout rooms in Zoom sessions to facilitate discussions between research groups.

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2023
Modified by: Nathaniel Szymczak
